Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance encounters a person who is visibly upset and crying about a recent event.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story: I was on my way to the church, my mind already reciting the prayers I would soon lead for the most significant religious holiday of the year. The community expected me to be there, to guide them, to be the steady presence they relied on. As I hurried along the path, I saw Anna, an acquaintance from the neighborhood, sitting on a bench, her shoulders shaking with sobs. I hesitated, torn. As an acquaintance, I felt the pull to stop, to offer comfort, to be the friendly face she might need in this moment of pain. But as a priest, I knew the congregation was waiting, counting on me to begin the service on time, to uphold the tradition that meant so much to them. My heart ached with the weight of both expectations, the urge to help Anna battling with the duty to my community. I stood there, caught between two worlds, unsure which path to take.
